Step 1 — events and initial condition
- Events: event1 and event2.
- Initial condition: event1 has happened (the system starts at event1).

Step 2 — transition rules
- After event1, event2 must happen.
- After event2, event1 must happen.
- Therefore the only possible infinite execution is an alternating sequence: event1, event2, event1, event2, ...

Step 3 — meaning of the conditions
- C1: "Event2 always happens." (Note: this phrase is ambiguous; two useful readings are:)
  - Reading A (strict): "event2 holds at every time point" — i.e. at every step in the execution, event2 occurs.
  - Reading B (liveness): "event2 occurs in every execution (e.g. infinitely often or eventually after event1)."
- C2: stated identical to C1 in your text (so same ambiguity).
- C3: "If C1 holds, then C2 holds." Formally: C1 → C2.

Step 4 — how they relate and final answer
- First, because C1 and C2 are the same statement as written, C3 is a logical tautology: for any proposition P, P → P is always true. So C3 is True regardless of whether C1 (and C2) is true or false.
- Second, about the truth of C1/C2 under the system:
  - Under Reading A (event2 at every time point): C1 is false, because at the steps where event1 happens, event2 does not hold simultaneously.
  - Under Reading B (event2 occurs in every execution / infinitely often): C1 is true, because starting from event1 the system alternates and event2 does occur (repeatedly).
- In either case, C3 remains True (tautologically) because it is of the form P → P.

Conclusion: C3 is True.

=== Step 2: Solution ===
True

Reason: C3 is of the form P → P (C1 and C2 are the same proposition), which is a tautology and therefore always true.

=== Context ===

Initially, event1 happened. After event1, no other events can happen. After event2, event1 must happen.

C3: C2 does not hold.

prediction_raw:
=== Step 1: Problem Breakdown ===
Step 1 — events and initial conditions
- Events: event1 and event2.
- Initial condition: event1 happened initially (i.e., at the start).

Step 2 — transition rules between events
- Rule A: After event1, no other events can happen. So once event1 has occurred, no subsequent events (including event2) can occur.
- Rule B: After event2, event1 must happen. This says if event2 occurs, then event1 must occur afterward. Given Rule A and the initial condition, event2 cannot occur (because event1 already happened initially and no events can occur after it), so Rule B is vacuously satisfied.

Step 3 — meaning of the sub-conditions
- C1: "Event1 happens or event1 happens." This is logically equivalent to "Event1 happens." (A or A ≡ A.)
- C2: "Event1 happens and C1 holds." This is "Event1 happens AND (Event1 happens)" which is equivalent to "Event1 happens." So C2 is true exactly when event1 happens.
- C3: "C2 does not hold." This is the negation of C2.

Step 4 — how they relate and final truth value
- From the initial condition, event1 happens. Therefore:
  - C1 is true.
  - C2 is true (since it requires event1 and C1, both true).
  - C3 is the negation of C2, so C3 is false.

Answer: C3 is False.

=== Step 2: Solution ===
False
